snippet: Paul Weitz’s “Lonely, I’m Not,” a damaged-boy-meets-defensive-girl story, stars a wonderfully matched, mismatched Topher Grace and Olivia Thirlby.
abstract: Ben Brantley reviews Paul Weitz play Lonely, I'm Not, directed by Trip Cullman at Second Stage Theater; Olivia Thirlby and Topher Grace star. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Ah, spring, when even a misanthrope's fancy turns to thoughts of love, or at least the vicarious experience of it. Seriously, don't you feel in the mood for a romantic comedy right about now -- one that isn't too sappy on the one hand, or too snarky on the other? Traditionally we look to the multiplexes to provide us with that fix. But this season you might want to check out what the New York theater has to offer in grown-up love stories. There's ''Once,'' of course, the multi-Tony Award nominee on Broadway, about young Dubliners making music as a substitute for love. But more urgently, through May 27 only, there's Paul Weitz's ''Lonely, I'm Not,'' which opened on Monday night at the Second Stage Theater, in a production starring a wonderfully matched, mismatched Topher Grace and Olivia Thirlby.

headline.main: A Match Oh So Perfectly Mismatched
